text: We'll hear argument next in Number 92-1750, John C. Fogerty v. Fantasy, Inc.--
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court:

Mr. Sidle, of course, this Court has to face up the Christiansburg case, where virtually identical language on attorney's fees was interpreted to suggest that we don't grant attorney's fees under it as respondents--
But the Christiansburg--
--so I think really we need to face up to what differences there are that would compel a different result here.
--Well, I think there's dramatic differences between civil rights cases and copyright cases.
Well, do you think Christiansburg was correctly decided?
--Christiansburg was correctly decided in the civil rights context, but I don't think this Court can carry over from the civil rights context to the commercial context of the copyright law area.
Well, you say civil rights context.
I think they are special.
What's your authority for that?
--I think just a general principle that Congress--
What's your authority from this Court?
--Well, I don't know that I can say there's any particular authority from this Court because it hasn't faced that issue.
Mr. Sidle, will you remind us where the language showed up first, because it is identical language?
The language showed up first in the Copyright Act.
Mr. Sidle, isn't it true that in 190... this statute was enacted in 1909.
Yes.
And at that time, isn't it fair to assume that the typical case Congress was thinking about was sort of a garden variety infringement suit, or something?
I think if we're looking back to 1909, the proper thing... the proper motive to project on Congress was that it was adopting the British Rule.
But to argue for the British Rule, that statute has been on the books for 87 years, or whatever it is, and nobody's ever adopted the British Rule.

--When you say, nobody's ever adopted the British Rule, we cite the Lewys case in our brief which says that that's what Congress did, and that's one of the pre-1976 act cases that Fantasy relies upon as authority that there was a dual standard.
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Well, that's the question we granted certiorari on, Mr. Robbins.

Well, I think, Your Honor, that the way the question was formulated was, should there be a dual standard and should the defendant receive its fees pursuant to a standard that says, do you get fees only when they're objectively unreasonable?
Certainly, the Ninth Circuit opinion gives one the impression that they thought that's what they were doing...
--Yes.
Well, that's the question we granted certiorari on, that we took the case to decide.
--Well, Your Honor, I'm prepared and happy to address the question of what standard should apply to prevailing plaintiffs.
Thank you, Your Honor.
Well, how was it interpreted before that language was adopted?
The patent cases?
Yes.

It's even-handed, and that's what we're asking for, is an even-handed standard, and I think Justice Ginsburg's point is well-taken, that Congress decided to change the patent law to make it only exceptional circumstances.
No, but they argued it had been so construed up until... I mean, even before the language went in the statute.

--But that, I submit, is... and I also submit, despite the analogy of patent law being closer to copyright than civil rights cases, I think there are also some unique considerations in copyright cases.
Thank you, Mr. Sidle.
